questions.text: What problem most deeply offends David when he first hears Goliath?
choices: The insult against the LORD and His people
The loss of trade with the Philistines
questions.explanation: He's provoked that an "uncircumcised Philistine" defies "the armies of the living God." (17:26, 36)

questions.text: Why does Saul initially reject David as a contender?
choices: David is too young and inexperienced at war
David is a shepherd and ritually unclean
questions.explanation: Saul: Goliath is a man of war "from his youth," but David is a youth. (17:33)

questions.text: David's argument to Saul for why he can face Goliath rests chiefly on…
choices: Prior deliverances from lion and bear by the LORD
questions.explanation: He grounds courage in God's past rescues as a pattern for future help. (17:34–37)

questions.text: Why does David remove Saul's armor?
choices: It is too heavy to lift
He has not "tested" it and chooses what he knows
questions.explanation: He hasn't proved it; he trusts familiar tools and God's deliverance. (17:38–39)

questions.text: Goliath's core boast is that victory belongs to…
questions.explanation: He embodies might/weaponry; David counters that "the battle is the LORD's." (17:43–47)

questions.text: What does David say the outcome will teach "all the earth"?
choices: There is a God in Israel who saves without sword or spear

questions.text: What turns Israel's fear into pursuit and victory?
choices: David's single faith-act and visible result
questions.explanation: David's strike triggers Israel's courage; they rise and pursue. (17:51–53)

questions.text: What most clearly reveals David's motive in fighting?
choices: The insult to God's name and the good of God's people
questions.explanation: He repeats concern for God's honor and Israel's welfare. (17:26, 36, 45–47)

questions.text: David calls Israel "the armies of the living God." Why is that phrase important here?
choices: It marks Israel as recently victorious
It frames the fight as God's, so Israel's identity gives courage

questions.text: Why does David take Goliath's sword to finish the kill?
choices: To show the enemy's weapon cannot save
questions.explanation: Thematically echoes "not by sword or spear"; the foe's blade seals his defeat. (17:47, 51)

questions.text: Why is Eliab's outburst significant to the story's meaning?
choices: It shows human misreading of godly zeal as pride
It proves David sought the reward
questions.explanation: Eliab mistakes faith for arrogance—common theme in call narratives. (17:28–30)
